block.p: I am disappointed that one of your reviewers -- once again -- has taken upon himself the noble task of reminding readers that they cannot possibly ''care'' about characters who are capable of making them laugh. I am referring to Albert Mobilio's review of T. C. Boyle's novel ''A Friend of the Earth'' (Oct. 8), in which he says, ''This kind of self-reflexive wisecracking provides a tonic jolt in some novels, but in a story this thin it only reminds us how little we care, how slight the tether is to any larger drama.'' I care deeply about the members of my family, but their antics often send me into hilarity, in spite of the ''larger drama.''
Spare me the weighty values that seem to inform many of your reviewers' sensibilities. Comedy, parody, satire are worthy vehicles in which to dissect human foibles and tribulations.
